conclusion: To determine when the two objects (A and B) are farthest apart, we need to analyze their positions as functions of time \( t \).
We can obtain these positions by finding the area under the velocity-time graph for each object.
The area under the curve represents the displacement of an object over time.
For Object A, from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = t_1 \), the area under the curve is negative.
For Object A, from \( t = t_1 \) to \( t = t_2 \), the area under the curve is positive.
For Object B, from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = t_2 \), the area under the curve is positive.

premise: Using the areas under the curves, we can express the position of each object as a function of time.
conclusion: Position of Object A: \( s_A(t) = \int_{0}^{t} v_A(\tau) d\tau \).

premise: Since \( v_A(t) \) changes between negative and positive values.
conclusion: Position of Object A: negative for \( 0 \leq t < t_1 \), positive for \( t_1 \leq t \leq t_2 \).

premise: Using the areas under the curves, we can express the position of each object as a function of time.
conclusion: Position of Object B: \( s_B(t) = \int_{0}^{t} v_B(\tau) d\tau \).
Position of Object B: negative for \( 0 \leq t < t_2 \), positive for \( t_2 \leq t \).

premise: To find the time \( t \) when the objects are farthest apart, calculate the difference in their positions \( |s_A(t) - s_B(t)| \).
conclusion: For \( 0 \leq t < t_1 \), \( s_A(t) - s_B(t) = \text{negative value} - \text{negative value} > 0 \).

premise: Calculate the difference in their positions \( |s_A(t) - s_B(t)| \).
conclusion: For \( t_1 \leq t < t_2 \), \( s_A(t) - s_B(t) = \text{positive value} - \text{negative value} > 0 \).

premise: Calculate the difference in their positions \( |s_A(t) - s_B(t)| \).
conclusion: For \( t \geq t_2 \), \( s_A(t) - s_B(t) = \text{positive value} - \text{positive value} < 0 \).
